original_data.question: A 25-year-old male involved in a knife fight presents with a penetrating wound to the chest. The patient is unconscious and cannot provide any further history. Vitals show a temperature of 37-0°C (98.6°F), blood pressure of 85/55 mm Hg, pulse of 115/min, respirations of 19/min, and oxygen saturation of 92% on room air. On physical examination, the patient is diaphoretic and unresponsive. Extremities are pale and cool. There is a 3-inch long penetrating wound between the 3rd and 4th intercostal space on the left side of the chest, which is bleeding profusely. Transthoracic echocardiography reveals a full thickness penetrating injury to the right ventricular free wall. There are no apparent injuries to any coronary arteries or major branches. The patient is intubated and aggressive fluid resuscitation is initiated, including a blood transfusion. Which of the following is the best definitive surgical approach to take in this patient?

options.B: Watchful waiting while resuscitative fluids are initiated
options.C: Interrupted 2-0 polypropylene suture with supporting pledgets
options.D: Needle thoracostomy over the 2nd intercostal space

model_response:
The patient is in extremis and requires immediate surgery. The patient has a full thickness injury to the right ventricle, which is the most rapidly fatal cardiac injury. The patient is also in shock, which further supports the need for immediate surgery. The patient will require open cardiac massage to maintain cardiac output while the injury is being repaired. The definitive surgical approach will require a full sternotomy with cardiopulmonary bypass. A needle thoracostomy is performed in the 2nd intercostal space in the midclavicular line for emergency decompression of the hemithorax in a patient in shock with a suspected cardiac injury. A cardiac transplant is not an option.

Answer: OPTION C IS CORRECT.</s><s>

question_entities.definition: A person who belongs to the sex that normally produces sperm. The term is used to indicate biological sex distinctions, cultural gender role distinctions, or both.
The act of entering into or through something.
bodily injury caused by physical means, with disruption of the normal continuity of structures.
The upper part of the trunk between the NECK and the ABDOMEN. It contains the chief organs of the circulatory and respiratory systems. (From Stedman, 25th ed)
Individuals participating in the health care system for the purpose of receiving therapeutic, diagnostic, or preventive procedures.
Those forces and content of the mind which are not ordinarily available to conscious awareness or to immediate recall.
Record and study of past events.
A table of data specifically regarding vitals.
The measure of the level of heat of a human or animal.
PRESSURE of the BLOOD on the ARTERIES and other BLOOD VESSELS.
A metric unit of length equal to one thousandth of a meter (10E-3 meter) or approximately 0.03937 inch.
The rhythmical expansion and contraction of an ARTERY produced by waves of pressure caused by the ejection of BLOOD from the left ventricle of the HEART as it contracts.

The act of breathing with the LUNGS, consisting of INHALATION, or the taking into the lungs of the ambient air, and of EXHALATION, or the expelling of the modified air which contains more CARBON DIOXIDE than the air taken in (Blakiston's Gould Medical Dictionary, 4th ed.). This does not include tissue respiration (= OXYGEN CONSUMPTION) or cell respiration (= CELL RESPIRATION).
Unmodified air as existing in the immediate surroundings.
Systematic and thorough inspection of the patient for physical signs of disease or abnormality.
Individuals participating in the health care system for the purpose of receiving therapeutic, diagnostic, or preventive procedures.
Pertaining to, characterized by, or promoting sweating, e.g. procedure or an agent that promotes sweating.
Not responding to treatment.
The farthest or outermost projections of the body, such as the HAND and FOOT.
A clinical manifestation consisting of an unnatural paleness of the skin.
To lower the temperature of something.
bodily injury caused by physical means, with disruption of the normal continuity of structures.
Space of compartment of trunk bounded by the upper and lower surfaces of two consecutive ribs.
Being or located on or directed toward the side of the body to the west when facing north.
The upper part of the trunk between the NECK and the ABDOMEN. It contains the chief organs of the circulatory and respiratory systems. (From Stedman, 25th ed)
Bleeding or escape of blood from a vessel.
Ultrasonic recording of the size, motion, and composition of the heart and surrounding tissues. The standard approach is transthoracic.
Wide in width, extent or cross-section.
Wounds caused by objects penetrating the skin.
The lateral segment of the right ventricular wall, excluding the anterior and inferior right ventricular wall.
Used with anatomic headings, animals, and sports for wounds and injuries. Excludes cell damage, for which "pathology" is used.
One of two arteries that arise from the aortic sinuses of the ascending aorta and supply blood to the myocardium
A part of a forking structure; a division or offshoot from a main stem.
Individuals participating in the health care system for the purpose of receiving therapeutic, diagnostic, or preventive procedures.
Behavior which may be manifested by destructive and attacking action which is verbal or physical, by covert attitudes of hostility or by obstructionism.
The restoration to life or consciousness of one apparently dead. (Dorland, 27th ed)
The introduction of whole blood or blood component directly into the blood stream. (Dorland, 27th ed)
Individuals participating in the health care system for the purpose of receiving therapeutic, diagnostic, or preventive procedures.
